1.words: Okay. First is the purpose of this conversation. We want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across neighborhoods and communities and build an ecosystem of listening where every community member's story contributes to our shared understanding in a stronger, more inclusive Boston. To achieve this goal, we invite you to engage in a new kind of conversation, one centered on sharing personal stories from our own lives and experiences, rather than beginning the conversation with our positions on issues. This approach aims to help build connections and facilitate conversations that deepen mutual understanding. Secondly, I want to address what will happen to the recording of this conversation. Following our meeting today, the audio recording will become part of a collection of conversations. This conversation, along with all the other conversations that are taking place throughout the city will be shared with members of the Real Talk at Boston team, which consists of 14 community-based organizations in the city of Boston and the MIT Center for Constructive Communication. Thirdly, all conversations that will be part of this effort will become part of the conversation platform that is developed by the non-profit organization, Cortico CCC's Development arm. The FORA system creates a transcript for each record conversation and uploads both the transcript and audio recording to the Explorer tool. The system highlights keywords that emerges across the different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets and discover patterns. What we want to accomplish today is to be in the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to the MIT Center for Constructive Communication to retain the recording of this conversation in accordance with the mission of the Real Talk at Boston and transforming Boston into a listening city. You also understand that the conversation will be part of the Real Talk at Boston Public Conversation Collection. With the goal to foster constructive conversations across the city. CCC will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that goal and with that mission to develop methods and tools that foster constructive communication in local communities. Participation in this conversation is voluntary and you can withdraw any time without consequences. Sections will be recorded, but you can opt out and have this recording deleted. Only the research team at the MIT CCC will have access to your data. Your identity will be protected and information won't be shared without permission unless required by law. There are minimal foreseen risk. However, as with any conversation, there is a chance that you'll hear stories that elicit strong emotions. I will support you in hosting a safe conversation where you only share what you feel comfortable sharing. Do you consent to this? If you agree to this, if you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree.

1.linked_words: Do you consent to this? If you agree to this, if you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree.
If you agree to this, if you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree.

4.words: Great. Yeah, it didn't have to be one by one, it could be anything. Lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from others in this conversation and to support these goals, we'll introduce a few guidelines for our conversation. One, speak for yourself and out of your own experiences, not your opinions. Two, allow others to speak for themselves. Three, share the time, allow others to finish speaking. Take turns. Four, stay curious. Ask honest questions. Five, pause, take time for reflection. Six, listen generously, assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. Is everyone on board with these guidelines?

15.words: Thank you. And so for the rest of this conversation, and we really want to more learn it is going to be more learning more about and focusing on your experiences in living in the city and for those who maybe are on the outskirts of the city still, there's a lot of interaction you have with the city. So kind of think about that scope when you're answering the questions. So the next question would be, could you describe a specific time when you felt really supported by the community in Boston? So I would love to hear about maybe who was there, maybe what it was and what made that moment maybe special or more meaningful and that caused you to feel supported. You can take your time and think about a moment, too.

16.words: I can say something. We moved from the suburbs of Boston into South Boston in 2015. Having lived in the suburbs all my life, this was the first time I lived in the city and our neighbors were extremely welcoming. South Boston's generally a very young community, which is kind of difficult sometimes for us, but the people on our street have been there for a long time and just not all of them, but many of them were very welcoming and maintain that sort of neighborly way toward us.

15.segment_words: our neighbors were extremely welcoming. South Boston's generally a very young community, which is kind of difficult sometimes for us, but the people on our street have been there for a long time and just not all of them, but many of them were very welcoming and maintain that sort of neighborly way toward us.
15.linked_words: could you describe a specific time when you felt really supported by the community in Boston?

17.words: I can share a similar-ish story. Last summer, my neighborhood, the three streets around, although I live in Fenway, so all of Fenway was invited, but primarily the three streets around hosted a block party and it was really nice to meet people all ages in the neighborhood. We even created a group chat with a bunch of people in the neighborhood that were young and had just moved to Boston. So it was really nice. And now we know who's in the area and who to reach out for if things happen in our building or just updates in the general neighborhood.

22.words: I can start. I would say transportation. Public transportation is an issue in the day-to-day for myself, a lot of other people in the area and it's very inconvenient and can be costly and if things happen like work being done, there's really no successful alternatives that can get you to point A and B in a timely manner. And also cost of living and housing go up every single year, but a lot of the pay doesn't increase to match that.

23.words: Yeah, I think I can speak on moving here, it's just the cost of living is just extremely high and I think that can be touched on, I don't think wages are keeping up with just how much and how quickly things are increasing and I don't know if it's necessarily tied to inflation. I think it's just going up because they can, and I know we do have a housing shortage in the area, but it's becoming out of reach for a lot of people, so that's definitely a huge struggle. And also share the same sentiments about public transit. It's definitely a struggle.

35.words: Okay. This is more like a demographic thing for me that where we live in South Boston, you see the difference between our ages and most of the people are like Caroline's age. 45.words: And you also don't have a lot of people personally my age who live there who have cars. So it's all reliant on that. And like you said, you're not really going to leave. You have to do an Uber and Uber's expensive and they do surge charges when everyone's trying to, if they want to go out on a Saturday night and leave. So then it's easier to just walk to the area that's there. So I think that it does tie back to public transportation as well. And the lack of parking in South Boston specifically to Boston in the city, there's no parking garages in South Boston. There is no parking lots in South Boston. It is all street parking and you have, for example, in my building is three floors and four roommates to each floor. So it's 12 people and there's probably enough to fit one car outside of our house. So then you have all those people that aren't going to bring a car, you can't fit it anywhere. And so I think it gets crowded fast on the streets for parking to.
